addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight, Principall Secretary to her Ma
tie
.

20 Au
g
1589
From M
r
Bodley.

page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
H. immediatly uppon
e wri-
ting of my last, whiche I sent from hens
e 15 of
this present, we heard of
e losse of
e house of
Heel,
where
e souldiers, being about
e nomber of 200 were
almost all ether slaine or taken: whether by
e Go-
verno
rs
treason, or for want of circumspection, we are
not yet informed from
e Count. But
e Enemie
tooke it soddainly by force, while
e Governo
r
and
20 others in his company, were come wtout
e fort,
and in parle. Heeruppon it is generally thought,
at
e Enemie will bend all his forces, to make a
bridge to passe
e Wael, right over against
e house
of
Brakel,
where he hath already so planted his
artillerie, as nether shippe nor boate can passe, but
in daunger of shotte, and besides hath all thinges
in a readines that should serve for his bridge: as
this bearer, who came newly from thens, can signifie
more at large. The
Count Neuwenar
and the
Count of Overstein
are written unto from hens, to send
fower or five c
o
panies more to
Count Maurice
, whiche
with those
at he hath already, may make 2000 men.
But if
e Enemies purpose in making
at bridge take
effect,
e losse of
Bommel
must folowe of necessitie,
and of all
e places there adjoining, and shortly after
of
Utrecht,
and those other Provinces. Whiche is all
come uppon us, through
e losse of
Gertrudenbergh.
For
e Garrison there was alwaies able to hinder suche
attemptes of
e Enemie. Nevertheles I am very
well assured,
at if any great extremitie shall
come uppon
e Contrey, they will exclame very
bitterly, and by some mens instigation, cast
e fault
uppon her Ma
tie
for w
t
holding her assistance, not con-
sidering, as I have told
e Councell of state, w
at
forces they bare her Ma
tie
in hand, at
e making of
fol.82v
the contract, that they would maintene for
e filde,
and howe at this present, being pressed by
e Ene-
mie, they are not able in all, as farre as I can
learne by any enquirie, both horse and foote ac-
counted, to raise 3000 men. Uppon
receat of
e
States
resoluc
o
n, w
ch
I sent yo
r
H. in
my last, for as muche as they pretend to have sent
e Articles to their Principals, w
ch
I am persuaded
is not done, I and
M
r
Gilpin
have thought it be-
hoofull for her Ma
ties
service, to write particular
letters to
e severall states of every Province, to
suche effect, as by
e copie inclosed may appeare
to yo
r
H. If
e Articles have bin sent unto
them, it will serve to hasten
e returne of their
answears. If
ei have not bin sent, yet it will be
a meanes to give
e contrey to understand, howe
her Ma
tie
and they are wronged by
e sinister
courses of their statesmen. The
Councell of state
hath sent of late, and therein re-
q
e
sted my letters of furtherance, to
e Garrison townes
of
Berghen,
Flushing,
Ostend
and
e
Brill,
that
when those companies shalbe landed, whiche her
Ma
tie
hath promised to send hither, they may be
receaved by them, and
to
e like nomber of
e old
companies drawen out to
e present service, because
it is supposed
at
e newe are both weake, and not
thorowly trained. And to
e ende
e Garrisons
might make
e lesse difficultie, they have intreated
M
r
Gilpin to goe w
t
their letters to
e Governo
rs
,
and to use suche persuasion, as he shall find re-
quisit.
And thus I take my humble leave. From
e Hage. Au
g
20 /89/ Yo
r
H most humbly
bounden Tho. Bodley
